ground_truth: The cheap glasses, the nut-brown head, the warm, eager eyes. He smiles and joins his hands together to exchange Godse's greeting. Godse moves his right hand rapidly from the stance of prayer to his jacket, in an instant — it holds a gun, and he fires point blank at Gandhi — loud, startling — once, twice, thrice. Gandhi's white shawl is stained with blood as he falls. Amid the screams and sounds of chaos we dissolve through to soldier's feet moving in the slow step, half-step, step of the requiem march. The huge funeral procession — crowds such as have never been seen on the screen massed along the route. People everywhere, clinging to monuments, lamp standards, trees — and as the camera pulls back from the funeral cortege it reveals more and more. We only hear a strange, rhythmic shuffling, pierced by an occasional wail of grief. We see the soldiers and sailors lining the route, their hands locked together in one seemingly endless chain. We see the two hundred men of the Army, Navy, and Air Force drawing the Army weapon-carrier that bears the body of Gandhi. And finally we see Gandhi lying on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by flowers, a tiny figure in this ocean of grief and reverence. Commentators from all over the world are covering the ceremony. We concentrate on one, let us say the most distinguished American broadcaster of the time, Edward R. As the cortege continues on its way, we get shots of the marching soldiers, of the faces of Sikhs, and Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Moslems from the north, Marathas from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, dark-skinned Keralans. We see the throng, following the weapon-carrier bier of Gandhi as it slowly inches its way along the Kings way. Mountbatten, tall, handsome, bemedalled, walks at the head of dignitaries from many lands, and behind them a broad mass of Indians. The camera picks out those who ride on the weapon-carrier with Gandhi's body: the stout, blunt, but now shattered Patel, Gandhi's son, Devadas, the strong, almost fierce face of Maulana Azad, now angry at the Gods themselves, and finally Pandit Nehru — a face with the strength of a hero, the sensitivity of a poet, and now wounded like the son of a loving father. The porter has glanced down the corridor, where from his point of view we can just glimpse the European talking with the conductor. He looks up suddenly then turns back quickly to his work. Gandhi glances at the door to see what has frightened him so. The European and the conductor push open the door and stride in. Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The inexpensive spectacles, the chestnut-brown head, the cordial, enthusiastic eyes. He beams and unites his hands together to swap Godse's salutation. Godse shifts his right hand swiftly from the stance of supplication to his coat, in a moment — it grips a firearm, and he discharges point blank at Gandhi — loud, shocking — once, twice, thrice. Gandhi's white wrap is spotted with gore as he collapses. Amid the shrieks and noises of turmoil we dissolve through to soldier's feet progressing in the slow pace, half-step, pace of the dirge march. The enormous memorial procession — multitudes such as have never been observed on the screen clustered along the path. People everywhere, clinging to statues, lamp posts, trees — and as the camera pulls back from the funeral cortege it exposes more and more. We only hear a peculiar, rhythmic shuffling, pierced by an occasional lament of sorrow. We see the soldiers and sailors aligning the path, their hands locked together in one seemingly endless chain. We see the two hundred men of the Army, Navy, and Air Force hauling the Army weapon-carrier that holds the corpse of Gandhi. And ultimately we see Gandhi resting on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by blossoms, a diminutive figure in this sea of lamentation and veneration. Commentators from all over the globe are reporting the ceremony. We focus on one, let us say the most distinguished American announcer of the period, Edward R. As the cortege progresses on its course, we get shots of the marching soldiers, of the faces of Sikhs, and Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Moslems from the north, Marathas from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, dark-skinned Keralans. We see the crowd, trailing the weapon-carrier bier of Gandhi as it slowly inches its course along the Kings way. Mountbatten, tall, attractive, bemedaled, strides at the head of emissaries from many nations, and behind them a wide mass of Indians. The camera selects those who ride on the weapon-carrier with Gandhi's remains: the stout, blunt, but now shattered Patel, Gandhi's son, Devadas, the strong, almost fierce visage of Maulana Azad, now enraged at the Deities themselves, and ultimately Pandit Nehru — a face with the strength of a champion, the sensitivity of a bard, and now wounded like the son of a loving patriarch. The porter has glanced down the hallway, where from his perspective we can just glimpse the European conversing with the conductor. He glances up abruptly then turns back swiftly to his task. Gandhi glances at the door to see what has alarmed him so. The European and the conductor push open the entrance and stride in. Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The cheap glasses, nut-brown head, and warm, eager eyes. He smiles and joins his hands to exchange Godse's greeting. Godse swiftly moves his right hand to his jacket, pulls out a gun, and fires at Gandhi — loud, startling — three times. Gandhi's white shawl is stained with blood as he falls. Amid chaos and screams, we transition to soldiers' feet moving in the slow steps of the requiem march. The massive funeral procession — unprecedented crowds line the route. People clinging to monuments, lamp standards, and trees — as the camera pulls back, more are revealed. We hear rhythmic shuffling, pierced by occasional wails. Soldiers and sailors line the route, hands locked in an endless chain. Two hundred men from the Army, Navy, and Air Force draw the weapon-carrier bearing Gandhi's body. Gandhi lies on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by flowers, a tiny figure in this ocean of grief and reverence. Commentators worldwide cover the ceremony. Focus on the most distinguished American broadcaster, Edward R. As the cortege proceeds, we see shots of marching soldiers, Sikhs, Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Muslims, Marathas, Parsees, Keralans. The throng follows the bier slowly along Kingsway. Mountbatten, tall, handsome, bemedalled, leads dignitaries from many lands, followed by a mass of Indians. The camera captures those riding with Gandhi's body: the stout, shattered Patel, Gandhi's son Devadas, the strong, fierce face of Maulana Azad, now angry at the Gods, and Pandit Nehru — a face with a hero's strength, a poet's sensitivity, now wounded like a loving father's son. The porter glances down the corridor, seeing the European with the conductor. He looks up, then quickly returns to his work. Gandhi glances at the door to see what frightened him. The European and conductor enter, and Gandhi is incredulous at being addressed this way.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The nut-brown head, cheap glasses, warm eyes. He smiles, joins hands to greet Godse. Godse swiftly moves his hand from prayer stance to his jacket, pulls out a gun, and fires point-blank at Gandhi — three times. Gandhi's white shawl stains with blood as he falls. Amid screams and chaos, we see soldiers marching in slow, solemn steps. The massive funeral procession — unseen crowds line the route. People cling to monuments, lamp standards, trees. The camera reveals the vast assembly. We hear rhythmic shuffling and occasional wails of grief. Soldiers and sailors line the path, hands locked, forming an endless chain. Two hundred Army, Navy, and Air Force men draw the Army weapon-carrier holding Gandhi's body, surrounded by flowers. Commentators worldwide cover the ceremony, including Edward R. Soldiers march, and we see Sikhs, Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Moslems, Marathas, Parsees, Keralans following the bier along Kings Way. Mountbatten, with dignitaries, and a mass of Indians follow. On the weapon-carrier are Patel, Gandhi's son Devadas, Maulana Azad, and Pandit Nehru. Each shows grief and anger. The porter glances down the corridor, observing the European with the conductor, then returns quickly to work. Gandhi, surprised, glances toward the door as they stride in, incredulous at being addressed so abruptly.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The inexpensive, unrefined glasses perched on the nut-brown head, coupled with the warm and eager eyes. He offers a gentle smile and brings his hands together in a respectful manner to reciprocate Godse's greeting. Godse swiftly transitions his right hand from the prayer-like gesture to his jacket pocket, and in a mere instant, he brandishes a gun. He fires directly at Gandhi with a resounding loudness—startling and shocking—the shots ring out once, twice, and then a third time. Gandhi's pristine white shawl quickly becomes stained with the vibrant hue of blood as he collapses to the ground. Amid the panicked screams and the chaotic clamor, we seamlessly dissolve through to the scene of soldiers' feet, moving in a slow, deliberate step, half-step, step rhythm of the solemn requiem march. The extensive funeral procession moves forward, an impressive and enormous gathering that has never been captured before on the screen, with masses of people lining the route as far as the eye can see. Everywhere, people cling desperately to monuments, lamp standards, and trees—and as the camera gradually withdraws from the funeral cortege, it unveils an ever-expanding view. All we hear is a strange, rhythmic shuffling sound, intermittently pierced by a mournful wail of deep-seated grief. We observe the line of soldiers and sailors flanking the route, their hands interlocked to form what appears to be a continuous, unbroken chain. We witness the two hundred men from the Army, Navy, and Air Force as they collectively pull the Army weapon-carrier that solemnly bears the body of Gandhi. Ultimately, we see Gandhi himself lying on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by a profusion of flowers, a diminutive figure amidst this vast sea of sorrow and reverence. Commentators from various corners of the globe have converged to cover the momentous ceremony. Our focus narrows on one in particular, let's say the most prominent and respected American broadcaster of the era, Edward R. As the cortege continues its slow, deliberate progression, we are presented with shots of the marching soldiers, as well as the diverse faces of Sikhs, Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Moslems from the north, Marathas hailing from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, and dark-skinned Keralans. We observe the massive throng, as it faithfully follows the bier carrying Gandhi's body, slowly making its way along the grand Kingsway. Mountbatten, tall and handsome, adorned with medals, leads the dignitaries from numerous lands, and behind them trails a sweeping mass of Indians. The camera diligently picks out those individuals who accompany Gandhi's body on the weapon-carrier: the stout, straightforward, yet now grief-stricken Patel, Gandhi's son Devadas, the strong, intense face of Maulana Azad, his expression now one of anger towards the very Gods, and, finally, Pandit Nehru—a visage possessing the fortitude of a hero, the sensitivity of a poet, and now wounded like a son mourning a beloved father. The porter casts a quick glance down the corridor, where, from his perspective, we can just faintly catch a glimpse of the European engaged in conversation with the conductor. He abruptly looks up with a sense of urgency and then quickly redirects his attention back to his tasks. Gandhi casts a look toward the door to discern what has caused such alarm. The European and the conductor forcefully push open the door and stride in assertively. Gandhi is left incredulous, taken aback that he is being addressed in such an impertinent manner.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Perched upon a nut-brown head, the inexpensive, unrefined glasses appear alongside warm and eager eyes, creating a striking image. He offers a gentle, heartfelt smile and brings his hands together in a respectful manner, reciprocating Godse's greeting with a sincere gesture. In a matter of moments, Godse swiftly transitions his right hand from the prayer-like gesture to his jacket pocket, and in a mere instant, he brandishes a gun. He fires directly at Gandhi, with a resounding loudness that startles and shocks—shots ringing out once, twice, and then a third time. Gandhi's pristine, immaculate white shawl swiftly becomes stained with the vibrant crimson hue of blood as he collapses to the hard ground. Amid the panicked screams and the chaotic clamor that ensues, we seamlessly dissolve to the scene of soldiers' feet, moving with a slow, deliberate step, half-step, and step rhythm of the solemn requiem march. The extensive funeral procession moves forward, an impressive and enormous gathering that has never before been captured on the screen, with masses of people lining the route as far as the eye can see. Everywhere, individuals cling desperately to prominent monuments, lamp standards, and trees—and as the camera gradually withdraws from the funeral cortege, it unveils an ever-expanding, panoramic view. All we hear is a strange, rhythmic shuffling sound, intermittently pierced by a mournful wail of deep-seated grief. We observe the long line of soldiers and sailors flanking the route, their hands interlocked to form what appears to be a continuous, unbroken chain of unity. We witness the two hundred men from the Army, Navy, and Air Force as they collectively, with solemn duty, pull the Army weapon-carrier that solemnly bears the lifeless body of Gandhi. Ultimately, we see Gandhi himself lying peacefully on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by a profusion of colorful flowers, a diminutive figure amidst this vast sea of sorrow and reverence. Commentators from diverse corners of the globe have converged to cover this momentous, historic ceremony. Our focus narrows on one in particular, let us say the most prominent and respected American broadcaster of the era, Edward R. As the cortege slowly continues its deliberate progression, we are presented with shots of the marching soldiers, as well as the diverse, varied faces of Sikhs, Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Moslems from the north, Marathas hailing from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, and dark-skinned Keralans. We observe the massive throng of mourners, as it faithfully follows the bier carrying Gandhi's body, slowly making its way along the grand Kingsway. Mountbatten, tall and handsome, adorned with medals, leads the dignitaries from numerous lands, and behind them trails a sweeping mass of Indians. The camera diligently picks out notable individuals who accompany Gandhi's body on the weapon-carrier: the stout, straightforward, yet now grief-stricken Patel, Gandhi's son Devadas, the strong, intense face of Maulana Azad, whose expression now one of anger directed towards the very Gods, and finally, Pandit Nehru—a visage possessing the fortitude of a hero, the sensitivity of a poet, and now wounded like a son mourning a beloved father. The porter casts a quick, furtive glance down the corridor, where, from his perspective, we can just faintly catch a glimpse of the European engaged in conversation with the conductor. He abruptly looks up with a sense of urgency and then quickly redirects his attention back to his pressing tasks. Gandhi casts a look toward the door to discern what has caused such obvious alarm. The European and the conductor forcefully push open the door and stride in assertively, leaving Gandhi incredulous, taken aback that he is being addressed in such an impertinent manner.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The cheap glasses perched unsteadily on his nose, highlighting his nut-brown head, and his warm, eager eyes sparkle with a genuine smile as he attentively joins his hands together, observing the traditional gesture to exchange Godse's greeting. In a swift and shocking move, Godse's right hand, initially in the stance of prayer, darts to his jacket with alarming speed, retrieving a hidden gun. He swiftly levels the weapon, aiming point-blank at Gandhi, and with a deafening series of explosions, he fires once, twice, thrice, each shot loud and startling, echoing through the air. Gandhi's pristine white shawl, a symbol of peace, is instantly marred with vivid splatters of blood as he collapses to the ground. The immediate aftermath is a cacophony of screams and chaos, a turmoil that fades into the somber, measured rhythm of soldiers' feet moving in the methodical cadence of a requiem march. The scene unfolds into a vast, unparalleled funeral procession, crowds of people so dense they have never been captured on screen with such magnitude, lining the procession route. Everywhere, individuals cling to towering monuments, lamp standards, and branches of trees, desperately trying to witness this historic moment. As the camera gradually pulls back from the solemn funeral cortege, it reveals an ever-expanding sea of mourners. In the midst of this, a strange, rhythmic shuffling sound dominates, interrupted only by the sporadic, heart-wrenching wail of grief. Along the route, soldiers and sailors form an unbroken human chain, their hands firmly locked together in a continuous line. Simultaneously, two hundred uniformed men of the Army, Navy, and Air Force laboriously draw the Army weapon-carrier, which bears the revered body of Gandhi, himself lying serenely amidst a dense array of flowers, a small but profoundly significant figure within this overwhelming ocean of grief and reverence. Commentators from across the globe document the ceremony, but we focus on a particular voice—the renowned American broadcaster of the era, Edward R. Murrow. As the cortege advances along its path, the camera captures poignant shots of marching soldiers, diverse faces representing Sikhs, Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Muslims from the north, Marathas from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, and dark-skinned Keralans, all united in collective mourning. The vast throng follows the weapon-carrier bier of Gandhi, progressing slowly along Kingsway, a testament to the multitudinous respect he commanded. At the fore of the dignitaries walks Mountbatten, distinguished by his tall, handsome stature and laden with medals. Behind him trails a broad mass of Indians, diverse yet unified in their sorrow. The camera shifts focus to those who accompany Gandhi's body atop the weapon-carrier: Patel, once stout and blunt, now shattered by grief; Gandhi's son, Devadas, carrying his father's legacy; Maulana Azad, whose strong, fierce face betrays his anger, seemingly directed at the Gods themselves; and finally Pandit Nehru—a visage embodying the strength of a hero and the sensitivity of a poet, now bearing the emotional wounds akin to a loving son who has lost his father. Meanwhile, a porter casually glances down a corridor, where he catches a distant sight of a European conversing with the conductor. This prompts him to look up suddenly before hastily returning to his duties. Gandhi, sensing the porter's unease, casts a curious glance toward the door to discern the source of his anxiety. In that moment, the European and the conductor assertively push open the door, striding in with a commanding presence, leaving Gandhi incredulous and taken aback at being addressed with such unexpected directness.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The description begins with a focus on Gandhi's appearance as he warmly greets Godse, who quickly draws a gun and shoots Gandhi at point-blank range. Amid the ensuing chaos, Gandhi's white shawl is stained with blood as he falls. The scene transitions to a somber funeral procession with vast crowds lining the route, clinging to various structures, and creating a backdrop of rhythmic shuffling and intermittent wails of grief. Soldiers and sailors form a continuous chain along the procession, as 200 servicemen pull the Army weapon-carrier holding Gandhi's flower-adorned body. The coverage of commentators, including the distinguished American broadcaster Edward R., captures the diversity of mourners, from Sikhs and Tamils to Anglo-Indians and Marathas, following the bier along Kings Way. At the vanguard of the procession is Mountbatten, leading dignitaries from various nations, followed by a vast assembly of Indians. The camera highlights those accompanying Gandhi's body: the devastated Patel, Gandhi's son Devadas, the fierce Maulana Azad, and Pandit Nehru, whose face reflects both a hero's strength and a poet's sensitivity, now marked with the grief of a loving son's loss. Meanwhile, within a corridor, a porter notices a European and conductor's entrance, causing Gandhi to glance up in surprise at their abrupt manner of addressing him.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The cheap glasses, reminiscent of those worn by many scholars and intellectuals of his time, the nut-brown head, the warm, eager eyes. He smiles and joins his hands together to exchange Godse's greeting. Nathuram Godse, who had been a prominent member of the Hindu nationalist group Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, moves his right hand rapidly from the stance of prayer to his jacket, in an instant—it holds a gun, and he fires point blank at Gandhi—loud, startling—once, twice, thrice. Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, widely revered as the 'Father of the Nation' in India, has his white shawl stained with blood as he falls. Amid the screams and sounds of chaos we dissolve through to soldiers' feet moving in the slow step, half-step, step of the solemn requiem march. The huge funeral procession—crowds such as have never been seen on the screen massed along the route of Delhi's Raj Ghat. People everywhere, clinging to monuments, lamp standards, trees—and as the camera pulls back from the funeral cortege it reveals more and more. We only hear a strange, rhythmic shuffling, pierced by an occasional wail of grief. We see the soldiers and sailors lining the route, their hands locked together in one seemingly endless chain. We see the two hundred men of the Indian Army, Navy, and Air Force drawing the Army weapon-carrier that bears the body of Gandhi. And finally, we see Gandhi lying on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by flowers, a tiny figure in this ocean of grief and reverence. Commentators from all over the world are covering the ceremony. We concentrate on one, let us say the most distinguished American broadcaster of the time, Edward R. Murrow, known for his deep, resonant voice and profound coverage of World War II events. As the cortege continues on its way, we get shots of the marching soldiers, of the faces of Sikhs, and Tamils, Anglo-Indians, Moslems from the north, Marathas from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, dark-skinned Keralans. We see the throng, following the weapon-carrier bier of Gandhi as it slowly inches its way along the Kingsway, now known as Rajpath, a ceremonial boulevard in New Delhi. Lord Louis Mountbatten, last Viceroy of British India and soon-to-be first Governor-General of independent India, tall, handsome, bemedalled, walks at the head of dignitaries from many lands, and behind them a broad mass of Indians. The camera picks out those who ride on the weapon-carrier with Gandhi's body: the stout, blunt, but now shattered Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, India's first Deputy Prime Minister and a key figure in the country's unification, Gandhi's son, Devadas, the strong, almost fierce face of Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, a senior leader in the Indian freedom struggle and a staunch advocate for Hindu-Muslim unity, now angry at the Gods themselves, and finally Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru—India's first Prime Minister, a face with the strength of a hero, the sensitivity of a poet, and now wounded like the son of a loving father. The porter has glanced down the corridor, where from his point of view we can just glimpse the European, possibly a remnant of the colonial administration, talking with the conductor. He looks up suddenly, then turns back quickly to his work. Gandhi glances at the door to see what has frightened him so. The European and the conductor push open the door and stride in. Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner, perhaps a reflection of the tension during India's transition to independence.

The porter has glanced down the corridor where from his point of view we can just glimpse. the European talking with the conductor. He looks up suddenly then turns back quickly to his work. Gandhi glances at the door to see what has frightened him so. The European and the conductor push open the door and stride in. Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The scene begins with the assassination of Gandhi, shot point blank by Godse. Amid the chaos, the narrative shifts to the immense funeral procession. A vast crowd lines the streets: people cling to monuments and trees as soldiers and sailors form an unbroken chain lining the route. The procession is marked by a rhythmic shuffling, occasionally broken by cries of grief. Gandhi's body, adorned with flowers, is drawn on an Army weapon-carrier by military personnel, surrounded by a sea of mourners. Commentators like the renowned Edward R. provide coverage of the ceremony. The camera captures diverse faces in the crowd and highlights dignitaries, including Mountbatten and Gandhi's close associates like Patel, Devadas, Maulana Azad, and Pandit Nehru, each showing signs of profound grief. The somber atmosphere is palpable as the cortege moves slowly along the Kingsway.

cortege continues on its way we get shots of the marching soldiers of the faces of Sikhs and Tamils Gandhi glances at the door to see what has frightened him so We concentrate on one let us say the most distinguished American broadcaster of the time Edward R Godse moves his right hand rapidly from the stance of prayer to his jacket The European and the conductor push open the door and stride in Gandhi's white shawl is stained with blood as he falls Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner People everywhere clinging to monuments lamp standards trees — and as the camera pulls back from the funeral cortege it reveals more and more We only hear a strange rhythmic shuffling pierced by an occasional wail of grief The cheap glasses the nutbrown head the warm eager eyes in an instant — it holds a gun and he fires point blank at Gandhi — loud startling — once twice thrice the European talking with the conductor

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: We concentrate on one let us say the most distinguished American broadcaster of the time Edward R As the cortege continues on its way we get shots of the marching soldiers of the faces of Sikhs and Tamils AngloIndians Moslems from the north Marathas from the south blueeyed Parsees darkskinned Keralans We see the throng following the weaponcarrier bier of Gandhi as it slowly inches its way along the Kings way Mountbatten tall handsome bemedalled walks at the head of dignitaries from many lands and behind them a broad mass of Indians The camera picks out those who ride on the weaponcarrier with Gandhi's body the stout blunt but now shattered Patel Gandhi's son Devadas the strong almost fierce face of Maulana Azad now angry at the Gods themselves and finally Pandit Nehru — a face with the strength of a hero the sensitivity of a poet and now wounded like the son of a loving father The porter has glanced down the corridor where from his point of view we can just glimpse the European talking with the conductor He looks up suddenly then turns back quickly to his work Gandhi glances at the door to see what has frightened him so The European and the conductor push open the door and stride in Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner The cheap glasses the nutbrown head the warm eager eyes He smiles and joins his hands together to exchange Godse's greeting Godse moves his right hand rapidly from the stance of prayer to his jacket in an instant — it holds a gun and he fires point blank at Gandhi — loud startling — once twice thrice Gandhi's white shawl is stained with blood as he falls Amid the screams and sounds of chaos we dissolve through to soldier's feet moving in the slow step halfstep step of the requiem march The huge funeral procession — crowds such as have never been seen on the screen massed along the route People everywhere clinging to monuments lamp standards trees — and as the camera pulls back from the funeral cortege it reveals more and more We only hear a strange rhythmic shuffling pierced by an occasional wail of grief We see the soldiers and sailors lining the route their hands locked together in one seemingly endless chain We see the two hundred men of the Army Navy and Air Force drawing the Army weaponcarrier that bears the body of Gandhi And finally we see Gandhi lying on the weaponcarrier surrounded by flowers a tiny figure in this ocean of grief and reverence Commentators from all over the world are covering the ceremony
